game_description: "Makes my brain feel like it's having its first cup of coffee in the morning!" - Adam Savage Challenge your mind in Cubism, a deceptively simple puzzle game where you assemble increasingly complex shapes out of colorful blocks. Immerse yourself in a zen environment as you reason your way through 90 puzzles which will put your spatial thinking skills to the test. Features: - 90 challenging puzzles over two campaigns - Full hand tracking support - 120Hz support - Light & Dark mode - Passthrough mode
Languages: English, Chinese (China), French (Belgium), French (Canada), French (France), German, Japanese, Korean, Spanish (Argentina), Spanish (Chile), Spanish (Colombia), Spanish (Mexico), Spanish (Peru), Spanish (Puerto Rico), Spanish (Spain), Spanish (Venezuela)
review_1: I LOVE this game on the easy puzzles. I find it to be meditative and immensely satisfying. ü•∞ But for me, as the puzzles get harder I become increasingly frustrated ‚Äî to the point that I actually requested a refund! But I had enjoyed the easy puzzles SO MUCH that I couldn't get the game out of my head, and a few weeks later I bought the game again! What I do now is play until I get frustrated, then skip the rest of the puzzles on that level and move on to another level. But it would be nicer if I never had to get frustrated at all. Developers: Is there some way you could allow us to only see puzzles at our preferred level of difficulty? For example, add a setting to toggle the display of Easy | Medium | Hard puzzles. That way someone like me could limit the selection to easy puzzles and just enjoy breezing through them without frustration.
